sen.j: 洒落本（しゃれぼん）とは、江戸時代中期の戯作の一種である文学。
sen.e: Sharebon (Literally, witty book) is a type of gesaku literature in the mid-Edo period.
Sharebon (literally, witty book) is a type of gesaku literature in the mid-Edo period.
sen.cmt: スペース訂正と小文字に訂正をしました。
sen.e: Sharebon (literally, witty book) is a type of gesaku literature in the mid-Edo period.

sen.j: 半紙四分の一大の小型の版型で「こんにゃく本」とも呼ばれた。
sen.e: A small-sized format as large as quarter-sized hanshi (standard-sized Japanese paper for writing) was used for Sharebon books, which were also called 'konnyakubon' (literally "a konjak jelly book" due to their appearance).

A small-sized format as large as quarter-sized hanshi (standard-sized Japanese paper for writing) was used for Sharebon books, which were also called 'konnyakubon' (literally "a konjak jelly book" due to their appearance).

A small-sized format as large as quarter-sized hanshi (standard-sized Japanese paper for writing) was used for Sharebon books, which were also called 'konnyakubon' (literally "a konjak jelly book" due to their appearance).

sen.j: 遊所（遊廓など）での遊びについて書かれたものがほとんどである。
sen.e: Most Sharebon works were written about amusements in places for pleasure (such as yukaku, red-light districts).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処(三文に分割）
sen.e: Most Sharebon works were written about amusements in places for pleasure(such as yukaku, red-light districts.
sen.cmt: スペース削除しました。
sen.e: Most Sharebon works were written about amusements in places for pleasure(such as yukaku, red-light districts.

sen.j: 粋（いき）を理想とし、遊女と客の駆け引きを描写したり、野暮な客を笑いのめした内容が主であった。
sen.e: It idealized iki (the way of life, or style in fashion and art, combining material sensuality and elegant sophistication), and mainly described the stratagems between prostitutes in a pleasure quarters and their customers and had plots that made vulgar customers laughing stocks.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処(三文に分割）
sen.e: It idealized iki (the way of life, or style in fashion and art, combining material sensuality and elegant sophistication), and mainly described the stratagems between prostitutes in a pleasure quarters and their customers and had plots that made vulgar customers laughing stocks.

It idealized iki (the way of life, or style in fashion and art, combining material sensuality and elegant sophistication), and mainly described the stratagems between prostitutes in a pleasure quarters and their customers and had plots that made vulgar customers laughing stocks.

sen.j: 話を楽しむためだけでなく、実用的な遊び方指南や一種のガイド本として読まれた。
sen.e: People read them not only as enjoyable stories, but also as books that gave lessons in practical behavior for the pleasure quarters and as a kind of guidebook.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処(三文に分割）
sen.e: People read them not only as enjoyable stories, but also as books that gave lessons in practical behavior for the pleasure quarters and as a kind of guidebook.
People read them not only as enjoyable stories, but also as books that gave lessons in practical behavior for the pleasure quarters and as a kind of guidebook.

sen.j: もとは仮名草子の遊女評判記の類や、井原西鶴らの浮世草子にある遊里の描写がルーツである。
sen.e: They originate in books like some Yujo hyoban-ki (guidebooks to prostitutes in the red-light districts) in kana zoshi (novels written for women and children using kana rather than Chinese characters to make them easily understood), and the descriptions of pleasure quarters appearing in the Ukiyozoshi (literally, Books of the Floating World) of Saikaku IHARA and others.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: They originate in books like some Yujo hyoban-ki (guidebooks to prostitutes in the red-light districts) in kana zoshi (novels written for women and children using kana rather than Chinese characters to make them easily understood), and the descriptions of pleasure quarters appearing in the Ukiyozoshi (literally, Books of the Floating World) of Saikaku IHARA and others.

They originate in books like some Yujo hyoban-ki (guidebooks to prostitutes in the red-light districts) in kana zoshi (novels written for women and children using kana rather than Chinese characters to make them easily understood), and the descriptions of pleasure quarters appearing in the Ukiyozoshi (literally, Books of the Floating World) of Saikaku IHARA and others.

sen.j: 洒落本の元祖と目されるのは享保年間出版の『両巴巵言（りょうはしげん）』（1728年）、『史林残花』で、漢文体で江戸・吉原の風俗を滑稽に描いたものである。
sen.e: The "Ryoha shigen" (Words on the Wine Cup of the Pleasure Quarters, 1728) and "Shirin zanka" (Remaining Flowers of the Historical Forest), published in the Kyoho era and humorously describing the manners and customs of Yoshiwara in Edo (the most famous pleasure quarter during the Edo period) in kanbun (Sino-Japanese) style, are regarded as the first well-known sharebon works.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The "Ryoha shigen" (Words on the Wine Cup of the Pleasure Quarters, 1728) and "Shirin zanka" (Remaining Flowers of the Historical Forest), published in the Kyoho era and humorously describing the manners and customs of Yoshiwara in Edo (the most famous pleasure quarter during the Edo period) in kanbun (Sino-Japanese) style, are regarded as the first well-known sharebon works.

The "Ryoha shigen" (Words on the Wine Cup of the Pleasure Quarters, 1728) and "Shirin zanka" (Remaining Flowers of the Historical Forest), published in the Kyoho era and humorously describing the manners and customs of Yoshiwara in Edo (the most famous pleasure quarter during the Edo period) in kanbun (Sino-Japanese) style, are regarded as the first well-known sharebon works.

sen.j: のちには俗語の会話体を主としたものに変わっていった。
sen.e: Later they came to be written in a mainly conversation style using colloquial language.
Later they came to be written in a mainly conversation style using colloquial language.
Later they came to be written in a mainly conversation style using colloquial language.

sen.j: 无々道人（漢学者沢田東江の変名）の『異素六帖』（1757年）は仏者、歌学者、儒者の3人が色の道や遊里について面白おかしく議論するという内容である。
sen.e: In the "Iso Rokujo" (Six Booklets of Exotic Elements, 1757) written by 无々道人 (the nom-de-plume of Toko SAWADA, a scholar of the Chinese classics), three scholars, one in Buddhism, one in the study of waka poetry and one in Confucianism, have hilarious and frivolous discussions about sex, love affairs, and the pleasure quarters.
sen.cmt: 原文中、沢田東江のペンネームのみ、読み方が確認できなかったため、訳出では漢字のまま残しております。
sen.e: In the "Iso Rokujo" (Six Booklets of Exotic Elements, 1757) written by 无々道人 (the nom-de-plume of Toko SAWADA, a scholar of the Chinese classics), three scholars, one in Buddhism, one in the study of waka poetry and one in Confucianism, have hilarious and frivolous discussions about sex, love affairs, and the pleasure quarters.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを削除しました。「无々道人」の読みが確認できませんでした。
sen.e: In the "Iso Rokujo" (Six Booklets of Exotic Elements, 1757) written by 无々道人 (the nom-de-plume of Toko SAWADA, a scholar of the Chinese classics), three scholars, one in Buddhism, one in the study of waka poetry and one in Confucianism, have hilarious and frivolous discussions about sex, love affairs, and the pleasure quarters.

sen.j: 明和期の『遊子方言』（1770年）に至って洒落本のスタイルが整った。
sen.e: "Yushi Hogen" (The Rake's Patois, 1770) was written in the Meiwa era, and with it the style of the sharebon took final shape.
"Yushi Hogen" (The Rake's Patois, 1770) was written in the Meiwa era, and with it the style of the sharebon took final shape.
"Yushi Hogen" (The Rake's Patois, 1770) was written in the Meiwa era, and with it the style of the sharebon took final shape.

sen.j: 通人をきどる男がうぶな息子を連れて吉原に行くという筋で、茶屋の女房や遊女らとの会話を中心にして吉原の風俗や粋と野暮との対比を描いている。
sen.e: It is the story of a man who plays the connoisseur bringing his innocent son to Yoshiwara, and the author describes the manners and customs in Yoshiwara and the contrast between iki and yabo (vulgarity), and it takes conversations between the main characters and prostitutes in chaya (teahouses) and prostitutes in the red-light districts as its center.

It is the story of a man who plays the connoisseur bringing his innocent son to Yoshiwara, and the author describes the manners and customs in Yoshiwara and the contrast between iki and yabo (vulgarity), and it takes conversations between the main characters and prostitutes in chaya (teahouses) and prostitutes in the red-light districts as its center.

It is the story of a man who plays the connoisseur bringing his innocent son to Yoshiwara, and the author describes the manners and customs in Yoshiwara and the contrast between iki and yabo (vulgarity), and it takes conversations between the main characters and prostitutes in chaya (teahouses) and prostitutes in the red-light districts as its center.

sen.j: これが評判となり、類書が多く作られた。
sen.e: It earned a good reputation, and a lot of similar works were written.
It earned a good reputation, and a lot of similar works were written.
It earned a good reputation, and a lot of similar works were written.

sen.j: 遊里の細部を描写する「うがち」を特徴とする。
sen.e: This genre is characterized by 'ugachi', which describes the details of pleasure quarters.
This genre is characterized by 'ugachi', which describes the details of pleasure quarters.
This genre is characterized by 'ugachi', which describes the details of pleasure quarters.

sen.j: 洒落本の全盛は天明期前後で、代表的な作者は山東京伝らである。
sen.e: Sharebon prospered before and after the Tenmei era, and had representative authors such as Kyoden SANTO.
Sharebon prospered before and after the Tenmei era, and had representative authors such as Kyoden SANTO.
Sharebon prospered before and after the Tenmei era, and had representative authors such as Kyoden SANTO.

sen.j: 大田南畝もいくつかの変名で書いているといわれる。
sen.e: It is said that Nanpo OTA also wrote some works using several pseudonyms.
It is said that Nanpo OTA also wrote some works using several pseudonyms.
It is said that Nanpo OTA also wrote some works using several pseudonyms.

sen.j: 松平定信が主導した寛政の改革のもと、1791年に京伝の作（黄表紙と洒落本）が摘発された。
sen.e: Under the Kansei Reforms, which were led by Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA, Kyoden's works (sharebon and kibyoshi, or "yellow covers", illustrated books of popular fiction whose covers were yellow) were prosecuted in 1791.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処(三文に分割）
sen.e: Under the Kansei Reforms, which were led by Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA, Kyoden's works (sharebon and kibyoshi, or "yellow covers", illustrated books of popular fiction whose covers were yellow) were prosecuted in 1791.
sen.cmt: スペース訂正しました。
sen.e: Under the Kansei Reforms, which were led by Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA, Kyoden's works (sharebon and kibyoshi, or "yellow covers", illustrated books of popular fiction whose covers were yellow) were prosecuted in 1791.

sen.j: 版元の蔦屋重三郎は過料、京伝は手鎖50日という厳しい処罰を受けた。
sen.e: There was a severe punishment, and the publisher Juzaburo TSUTAYA assessed an enormous fine, while Kyoden himself was handcuffed for fifty-days.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処(三文に分割）
sen.e: There was a severe punishment, and the publisher Juzaburo TSUTAYA assessed an enormous fine, while Kyoden himself was handcuffed for fifty-days.
There was a severe punishment, and the publisher Juzaburo TSUTAYA assessed an enormous fine, while Kyoden himself was handcuffed for fifty-days.

sen.j: そのため、一時洒落本は姿を消した。
sen.e: Because of that, sharebon disappeared for a while.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処(三文に分割）
sen.e: Because of that, sharebon disappeared for a while.
Because of that, sharebon disappeared for a while.

sen.j: 寛政の後期から復活し、十返舎一九、式亭三馬らも洒落本を書いた。
sen.e: It began to revive in the late Kansei era, and writers such as Ikku JUPPENSHA and Sanba SHIKITEI wrote sharebon works as well.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It began to revive in the late Kansei era, and writers such as Ikku JUPPENSHA and Sanba SHIKITEI wrote sharebon works as well.
It began to revive in the late Kansei era, and writers such as Ikku JUPPENSHA and Sanba SHIKITEI wrote sharebon works as well.

sen.j: が、やがて遊里の世界を離れた滑稽本や人情本が主流になっていった。
sen.e: However, kokkeibon (humorous book) and ninjobon (romantic fiction), which described the world outside of pleasure quarters, gradually became the mainstream.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, kokkeibon (humorous book) and ninjobon (romantic fiction), which described the world outside of pleasure quarters, gradually became the mainstream.
However, kokkeibon (humorous book) and ninjobon (romantic fiction), which described the world outside of pleasure quarters, gradually became the mainstream.

sen.j: 洒落本の叢書として『洒落本大成』（29巻、補巻1、中央公論社）が刊行されている。
sen.e: As for series collecting sharebon, there has been published a "Sharebon taisei" (with twenty-nine volumes and one supplementary volume, by Chuo Koronsha).
As for series collecting sharebon, there has been published a "Sharebon taisei" (with twenty-nine volumes and one supplementary volume, by Chuo Koronsha).
sen.cmt: スペース訂正しました。
sen.e: As for series collecting sharebon, there has been published a "Sharebon taisei" (with twenty-nine volumes and one supplementary volume, by Chuo Koronsha).
